summary: A video tutorial on how to download and install Oracle VirtualBox on a Windows 7 system.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a title slide displaying the text "Install Oracle Virtual Box into Windows 7" along with the website "www.e-wrench.com" and a Creative Commons license symbol in the bottom right corner. The background is white with a blue gradient at the bottom. The scene transitions to a slide titled "Outcomes," listing three bullet points: "Download Oracle VirtualBox," "Install VirtualBox into Windows 7," and "Configure Default location of Virtual Machines to a PublicVM directory." The background remains white with a blue gradient at the bottom. The next slide is titled "Requirements," listing three bullet points: "Windows 7 Operating System," "VirtualBox," and "Enough memory(RAM) to run both your host operating system and you virtual operating system at the same time." The background is consistent with the previous slides. The video concludes with the same "Requirements" slide, maintaining the same layout and background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker introducing himself and the purpose of the video, sounding informative and professional. He describes Oracle Virtual Box, what it does, and the outcomes for the video. He sounds like he is reading from a script as he goes over the requirements. The clip ends abruptly with a short, non-specific sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer desktop featuring a blue background, with icons for the Recycle Bin, Mozilla Firefox, and an unidentified application with a shield logo. The scene transitions to a web browser window open to the VirtualBox website, displaying the VirtualBox logo and a welcome message. The website's content includes a description of VirtualBox as a powerful x86 and AMD64/Intel64 virtualization product, along with sections for news, hot picks, and links to Oracle VM VirtualBox. The video maintains focus on the VirtualBox website, highlighting its features and updates, with no significant changes in the environment or actions of any individuals. The atmosphere is informational, aimed at providing details about the VirtualBox software.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a website, "www.virtualbox.org," as a place to download VirtualBox. He mentions site features like screenshots, downloads, and documentation, emphasizing the good information it contains.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying the VirtualBox website, featuring a blue and white color scheme with the VirtualBox logo prominently displayed. The website's main page welcomes visitors and provides information about VirtualBox, a virtualization product for enterprise and personal use. The page includes sections for news, hot picks, and links to various resources such as documentation and community forums. The scene then transitions to a download page for VirtualBox, where users can find links to download the VirtualBox binaries for different operating systems, including Windows, Linux, and Solaris hosts. The download page also mentions the terms and conditions of the respective licenses. The video then shows a file download window, indicating that the user has chosen to download the VirtualBox 4.1.14-77440-Win.exe file, which is 89.7 MB in size. The user is prompted to save the file, with options to either save it or cancel the download. The video concludes with the download window still open, awaiting the user's decision.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a single male speaker calmly explaining how to download VirtualBox, mentioning clicking the download section and choosing the appropriate version for one's machine. He specifies "VirtualBox 4.1.14 for Windows host," noting its compatibility with both x86 and 64-bit Windows operating systems. He instructs to click on a specific option and save the file.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a file explorer window on a Linux operating system, specifically Ubuntu. The user is in the process of saving a file named "VirtualBox-4.1.14-77440-Win" as a binary file to the Downloads folder. The file explorer shows various folders such as FinchDreams, Firefox, FlashPlayer, Scratch, Storytelling Alice, and Ubuntu, with the Ubuntu folder highlighted. The user right-clicks on the Ubuntu folder, selects "Rename," and changes the folder name to "VirtualBox." The scene transitions to a web browser window open to the VirtualBox download page, where the user is downloading the VirtualBox 4.1.14 for Windows hosts file. The download progress bar shows 95% completion, with 10 minutes remaining at a speed of 65 KB/sec. The video concludes with the download nearing completion, with 6 minutes remaining at a speed of 265 KB/sec. The background of the video is a typical desktop environment with a focus on the file explorer and web browser windows.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker mentioning putting something on a local disk downloads and creating a separate directory called "VirtualBox". The speaker then states they will open it up and simply download the file. This is followed by the same male speaker stating it will be a very short download, and they mention approximately 10 minutes remaining.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen with a download manager window open, displaying two files being downloaded: "VirtualBox 4.1.14-77440-Win.exe" and "ubuntu-12.04-desktop-i386.iso." The download manager shows the progress of the files, with the VirtualBox file being downloaded at a speed of 165 KB/sec and the Ubuntu file at 139 KB/sec. The background features a web browser with a webpage titled "VirtualBox," which includes a disclaimer about the terms and conditions of the respective license for downloading the VirtualBox platform packages. The webpage also lists the different versions of VirtualBox available for Windows, OS X hosts, Linux hosts, and Solaris hosts. The download manager window has a "Clear List" button at the bottom, and the web browser has a search bar and navigation buttons at the top. The video captures the ongoing download process, with the progress bars updating in real-time, and the background webpage remains static throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with someone speaking in a relatively casual tone, suggesting while waiting for something to download, you can either "take a look at the user manual" or explore the site. They mention they will return after the download and proceed to set up "virtual box and Windows 7."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a download manager window, showing two files being downloaded: "VirtualBox 4.1.14-77440-Win.exe" and "ubuntu-12.04-desktop-i386.iso." The download progress bar indicates that the VirtualBox file is nearly complete, with only 4 seconds remaining. The background of the screen features a webpage with the VirtualBox logo and download links for various operating systems. The scene transitions to a desktop view with a blue background, showing icons for Mozilla Firefox, McAfee Security Suite, and the Recycle Bin. The video then shows a 3D perspective of the desktop, highlighting the Windows logo and the icons on the left side of the screen. The overall atmosphere is that of a typical computer setup, with a focus on downloading and managing files.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker noting the last few seconds of an installation process. He mentions that the virtual box has been downloaded and then instructs to close the folders. He says the next step is to set up the program on a Windows 7 computer. After that, silence is heard.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer desktop featuring the Windows 7 operating system, characterized by its iconic blue background and the Windows logo in the center. The taskbar at the bottom displays various icons, including the Start button, Internet Explorer, Windows Media Player, and the system tray with the time and date. The user right-clicks on the desktop, bringing up a context menu with options such as 'New', 'Refresh', 'View', 'Sort by', 'Group by', 'Align to grid', 'Paste', 'Paste shortcut', 'Paste shortcut and events_list.audio_caption: The speaker explains that once VirtualBox has been downloaded to a Windows 7 machine, the next step is to click on the .exe file and install it. The speaker advises the listener to right-click the start button to open Windows Explorer, then navigate to the location where the VirtualBox download resides. In this case, it's C:\Downloads. The speaker continues by describing how to click the VirtualBox file and then run it after a security warning appears. The speaker is male and speaks in an instructional tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a white background and a cursor icon, with a timestamp at the bottom indicating the date and time as 5/7/2012 8:51 PM. The scene transitions to the Oracle VM VirtualBox 4.1.14 Setup window, where the user selects the 'Custom Setup' option and navigates through the installation process. The user clicks on various features in the tree view, such as 'VirtualBox Application,' 'VirtualBox USB Support,' and 'VirtualBox Networking,' before proceeding to the 'Ready to Install' screen. A warning message about network interfaces appears, prompting the user to confirm the installation. The user clicks 'Yes,' and the installation process begins, indicated by a progress bar. The video then shows a 'User Account Control' dialog box asking for permission to install the software, followed by a 'Windows Security' dialog box asking if the user wants to install device software from Oracle Corporation. The installation continues with the progress bar filling up, and the video concludes with the installation nearing completion, as indicated by the nearly full progress bar. Throughout the video, the timestamp remains visible at the bottom of the screen, and the background remains consistent with a white setup window and a blue taskbar.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio opens with a male speaker stating that a security warning will come up multiple times during the install. He guides through the installation process, instructing to click 'next,' pick all items, and take the default location. He then mentions creating a shortcut on the desktop, giving a warning that network interfaces may be going up and down during installation, possibly causing disconnection. The speaker continues with instructions, clicking 'yes,' followed by 'install' to begin the installation. The tone remains instructional throughout. Subsequently, user account control windows pop up repeatedly, prompting clicks of 'yes,' and security warnings appear multiple times, requiring clicks of 'install' each time.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying the Oracle VM VirtualBox 4.1.14 installation completion window. The window features a graphic of an open box with the VirtualBox logo on top, set against a brown background. The text on the window reads "Oracle VM VirtualBox 4.1.14 installation is complete. Click the Finish button to exit the Setup Wizard." Below this message, there is a checkbox option labeled "Start Oracle VM VirtualBox 4.1.14 after installation," which is checked. The bottom of the window shows the version number "Version 4.1.14" and three buttons: "< Back," "Finish," and "Cancel." The date and time of installation are displayed as "5/7/2012 8:51 PM." The scene then transitions to a file explorer window showing the installation folder, with the file "VirtualBox-4.1.14-77440-Win.exe" highlighted, indicating the completion of the installation process. The video concludes with a view of the file explorer window, showing the installation folder and the file "VirtualBox-4.1.14-77440-Win.exe" with details such as the date modified, type, and size. The background of the desktop is a blue sky with clouds, and the taskbar at the bottom shows the Windows Start button and the date and time as "5/7/2012 8:54 PM."
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that "Oracle VM's installation is complete" in a neutral tone. He then instructs to "click finish". The clip ends with ambient sounds.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer desktop, showcasing a folder named "VirtualBox-4.1.14-77440-Win" located in the Downloads directory. The folder, created on 5/7/2012 at 8:54 AM, is highlighted, indicating it is selected. The scene transitions to the VirtualBox Manager window, which is empty, displaying a welcome message and instructions for creating a new virtual machine. The user then navigates to the "Settings" option within the VirtualBox Manager, opening a dialog box where the "General" settings are accessed. The user browses through various folders on the computer, including "Desktop," "Program Files," "Users," and "Libraries," before selecting the "Libraries" folder. The "Default Machine Folder" is set to "C:\Users\Public\VirtualBox," and the user clicks "OK" to confirm the settings. The video concludes with the VirtualBox Manager window displaying the updated settings, indicating the successful configuration of the default machine folder.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, whose voice is normal in tone, suggesting to "close this window right here" and introduces a virtual box, where the latest edition is installed. The speaker mentions a preference of where the virtual machines are installed, as these are usually in a directory, so if you want everyone to be able to use the virtual machines you have to change the preferences. The male speaker then discusses changing the folder and moves on to talking about the C drive, users, and public. The male speaker suggests making a new folder, called "public VMs for public virtual machines". The speaker suggests taking a look at some other settings, noting if you wish to keep your virtual machines private, and not let anyone else access them, you can. He clicks "OK" and finishes speaking, ending the clip with a simple "thank you".
